description.text:
These are lower profile hangers for 3M Command Strips. 3 versions, for mini, small, and medium Command Strips.

I originally had some small wire utensil holders, but the wire hanger pushed pictures out too far. These revised hangers keeps my picture frames closer to the wall. The small and medium protrude 1cm from the wall while the mini sticks out 0.5cm.

I printed these with a Monoprice Select Mini using Warm White eSUN PLA+ 1.75mm filament.

I like the original and printed it several times trying to get a pretty print. I had to use supports on one side or another and printing it handle up seems to be the way to go, but the gap between the head and the ball peen gets ugly so I bridged it and recreated the directional "suggestion" ;)

comments.text: I am going to try and "Bake" a print. Thomas Salanderer did it in this video http://bit.ly/2pvQgyY and he mentionned that although it shrinks somewhat it will toughen up quite a bit. Whether or not it fuses the horizontal print lines remains to be seen.

comments.text: I don't have to, I created this early in my 3d printing experience and only lately have come to realize that stress along the horizonal printing lines causes layer separation so in this case the head will break off quite easily if the layer haven't bonded well.

Godzilla Diorama-kit

.

How to make:

  • Find a nice display box, or platform (hobbystores online etc)
  • Resize the model parts to fit your display box/platform
  • Print the models, bend the tail part by heating it shortly! with a lighter.
  • Base coat the models
  • Glue them in the most dramatic scene on top of the platform
  • Paint the Godzilla and dry brush him
  • Paint water around the models use dark blue for the undisturbed sea
  • Use lighter blue and white paint around the ships and Godzilla model
  • Add "Still water" ontop of the paint. (transparent glue should also work)
  • To make the water splash up you can use tissue paper in combination with the "still water"
  • Make small rolls of tishue paper and place them in the "still water" substance where you want the waves to be.
  • Let the still water dry a little bit and use a toothpick to pull up the tissue paper from the water surface, and shape them into waves
    • Add more layers of still water.
  • Let everything dry completely before putting on the top part of the display
    (otherwise the "still water" / glue will condensate on the inside of your display!)

About the models:

  • "Godzilla model 2014" is a game rip, cut in half.
  • "Aircraft carrier USS Conrad" By supahotfire - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:889091
  • "Battleship remix" By elpllibrary - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:865117

(i'm getting a lot of downloads on my models, yet i don't see much people post back there printed results, if you want people continue to provide FREE models, please provide something back in return: Pictures, Comments, Tip money, a Thank you, a Follow or a Like...)

Thanks for watching, If you enjoy this model please support and check out my other models and tutorials:

title: M & M button
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was asked by a fellow maker friend to do make these M & M buttons for an outfit that she was hired to make for someones kid. I was surprised on how easy these actually were to design on TinkerCad.

I tried printing these on the Printrbot in our shop, but they just weren't able to get the fine detail. So next I'm taking them to the Zortrax and the Form1. One of those should give me a good enough print for the fine details on these.

UPDATE:
I printed the button on the Zortrax and it came out nice. I've redesigned the M logo to be a bit deeper. So I've replaced the file with a "r2" (revision 2) file.

Printer:

Zortrax

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Very High

Infill:

100%

You will need to drill a hole in the bottom support. I didn't think the little holes would print well on any of my printers. Basically I think it's more work than is worth it, when I can just drill the holes manually after printing.

You'll also want to super-glue the top to the bottom piece so that it looks like a big M&M. I printed mine in Z-ABS on a Zortrax printer. Then used a syringe of acetone to inject a small layer of acetone between the pieces then held them together until bonded.
You can find my design files on TinkerCad, and Tinker away with them.

This is a prototype of a non contact, low temp, heating coil that's embedded in a cylinder. I made this by subtracting a "spring" helical shape from a cylinder and then subtracting a center rod from the cylinder. It was possbile to push a thin wire into the channel without any effort although I could have used oil to lubricate the wire.
  • Created on a Form1 Clear 0.1mm resolution.
  • Object designed in truSpace CAD program.
  • Build time 30 minutes.

• This can be used as a low voltage, low temp heating element that does not contact the central channel.

  • The sprial was created by sweeping the surface of a 2mm rod with a 10 degree x tilt and a 20 degree y tilt. The resulting "spring" shaped object was then subtracted from a larger solid rod. The central channel was then subtracted from a smaller diamter than the inner diameter of the coil.

title: Prusa i3 direct drive extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a simple direct drive extruder for my mini prusa i3, and being a mini it does not have a lot of space so I made this. It sandwiches an E3D V6 style extruder onto the x-carriage. The extruder has mounting holes for a standard 40mm computer fan, and the idler lever uses a bearing that I scavenged from a larger computer fan. (Old computer parts are your friend.) Edit: Just added my x-carriage which allows for an additional 25mm of build space on the x axis!
Have fun everybody!

title: 12 hole Ocarina of Time - with triforce

description.text:
Hi guys ! Here's my ocarina. It respects all the laws to make a good ocarina and plays very well. It should even work on low-cost printers. It's an amazing print to see the capabilities of your printer and is fantastic if you wanna show it to your friends ;)
You can also find the holder on : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1726225
I hope you enjoy it ! ^^

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100

Notes:

You should print this instrument in the orientation of the file. The best is a 100 % infill (this should make it printable on 99 % of the 3d printers) but it is also possible to use solid infill every few layers.
I used sandpaper and some clear coat. Then I alternated between color and clear coat.

Software

I used Blender 2.7

author: KekkyBoi

description.text:
I recently built a TC1 Seismometer (http://tc1seismometer.wordpress.com/). Some of the required pieces were not readily available at a hardware store, so I decided to use my 3D printer to produce the parts.
The parts include:
-A slinky holder.
-A stabilization ring.
-A base cap.
-A pickup coil body.
-A damper tube holder. Note that this Thing is just for some of the components of the seismometer. There are many other parts needed for a complete assembly. Also, I'm not affiliated with the people who designed the TC1, so I'm unable to answer any assembly questions.

comments.text: Do you know where they keep their arduino code? Or how their AmaSeis program sniffs for data?
comments.author: smolkd

comments.text:
Dataq had a serial unit the DI-194rs that was used in a lot of the older stuff to digitize the signal from the pendulum after it was amplified and conditioned. This is good site for AmaSeis. I was playing with a design similar to this using abs pipe, a spring and the round magnets salvaged from old microwave ovens. Basically the same as the TC but inverted pendulum.
http://web.ics.purdue.edu/~braile/edumod/as1lessons/UsingAmaSeis/UsingAmaSeis.htmhttp://web.ics.purdue.edu/~bra...
I was also very interested in SID (Sudden Ionic Disturbance) which uses most of the same equipment, earthquakes tuned at 1hz and Sid around 5khz. The data you get out of it is pretty cool and the audio of the spectrum the earth creates is even cooler..
http://www.aavso.org/solar-sidshttp://www.aavso.org/solar-sid...
comments.author: smolkd

comments.text: what infill and number of shells did you use. Can we get a full size slinky holder. Gotta get one of these made.
comments.author: ve3sjk

comments.text:
It's a holder for a Slinky Jr. because that's what the BSU specs for the TC1 say to use. I'm sure you could use a full size Slinky, but you'd have to scale up other pieces, as well. A 3" Slinky isn't going to fit well inside a 3" tube, for instance.
Then again, they may have went with the Slinky Jr. for some reason other than its size. It could be that the smaller one simply picks up ground motion better or something. I don't really know... (Probably not. It's hardly a precision instrument...)
comments.author: ve3sjk

comments.text: The files look like they are maybe 1/10th scale?
comments.author: smolkd

comments.text:
They all end up the right size in my Afinia program. The ring and the base should have a roughly three inch interior diameter, the wire spool should have a 1 inch inside diameter, and the slinky thing should be the right size for a Slinky Jr. (Not a full size Slinky).
They were designed in inches, though, so if your printer program is treating the dimensions as millimeters, you might have to make adjustments.
comments.author: smolkd

comments.text: Thanks! The in to mm makes sense; after scaling the base cap by 25.4 the ID is slightly over 3".

author: ncbob

description.text:
This is my attempt at a design for a skew planar 5.8ghz soldering jig after spending much time fiddling with soldering each lobe separately. The jig is made to hold all pieces at the right position and angle and can be conveniently disassembled when done to remove the antenna making it easy to solder all the pieces at once and save time. Wire length - 53mm wire length, 13mm side bends (from IBcrazy's tutorial)
http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1388264 Refer to instructions tab on how to assemble/use and print settings. I'll be posting test results soon. If this helped you, I'd love to see images or comments with feedback!

All pieces were printed at .1mm resolution (i dont think higher will work), 2 shells, and 15% infill. Skew Planar:
Print 2 main halves, 4 clips, and one bottom piece.
Assemble according to image
Lobes must be bent separately and then placed the jig. The more easily they fit into the printed grooves, the better. Cloverleaf:
Design not complete

comments.text: Fantastic! I have used your Thing to make a 5.8ghz, 2.4ghz and 900mhz antennas for my Octocopter. I even scaled it to 2x so that I could use 1/16" welding wire to make a more robust 900mhz antenna. I used the dimensions from http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1388264http://www.rcgroups.com/forums.... Any plans on making a cloverleaf version for the transmitters? or even a 5 blade version for even better receive antennas? My Octocopter looks very cool with all three frequency antennae hanging off of it: 5.8ghz=FPV video / 2.4ghz=R/C Radio / 900mhz=telemetry.
comments.author: WardElder

comments.text: can you please explain how you used this to make a 900mz antenna? In other words did you have to size it up? To what scale?
comments.author: WardElder

comments.text: I have posted my 900mhz model. It is 2X the size to allow for thicker wires.  As you can see I extend the wires well past the edges of the jig.  The jig holds things in place to allow for soldering.  I also messed up and used hot glue.  This screws with the SWR.  I will replace the hot glue with epoxy as epoxy does not seem to bother the SWR.
comments.author: antslake

comments.text: I did scale it up to handle the thicker wire I used.  I only scaled it up a small amount.  I use it as a guide for the angles and to hold the antenna still while I solder.  for a 2.4ghz and a 900mhz antennas the wire extended out past the edges of the guide.  To me the guide is not needed to set the lengths of the antenna wires.  It is just used to hold things still while I solder them together.  I will try to post pictures of what I did.
comments.author: antslake

print_settings.Notes:: Printed upright with the opening facing the bed.

description.text: Simple blade cover for scalpels like No. 3. Customizable for other tool handles.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.27mm

Notes:

Printed upright with the opening facing the bed.

Fitting your handle

3D prints don't always come out accurate, or you might have measured your tool handle wrong, or you have more than one but different tool handles, or… something else caused the opening to be too tight. To fit it, simply heat your tool handle with a lighter or torch, then press the blade cover on. Let it cool down, and it should fit snugly and not get loose by itself.

Optionally, you cut print this thing with a thin wall, only using 2 or 3 shells of filament (calculate 2 or 3 times your nozzle size), so it can flex when you put it on the blade.

Marking it

I have multiple tool holders with different blades, which I use for different purposes. Since I cannot see which blade I'm grabbing when the cover is still on, I traced the blade outlines on the sides of the cover with a non-erasable pen.

comments.text: We use these scalpels in  paper conservation labs, and do reuse the blades for a bit. Love the cover!

comments.text: I often use them for postprocessing 3d-printed objects, and cutting paper, and to be fair the only reason I use them is because I had the handles lying around and I found cheap replacement blades in a pack of 100 on eBay, and I don't have an X-Acto knife.
comments.author: CLine

comments.text: Thanks for the info - I'm always on the lookout for new and better tools! I didn't realize there were scalpels with replaceable blades.
comments.author: rohieb

comments.text: For surgical scalpels like these, the blades must be replaceable because of hygiene reasons and because they get dull reasonably fast.

description.text:
I bought the Daewon 3D Printer Clogged Extruder Nozzle kit from amazon. I assumed that the drill screwdriver and bits would come in some kind of holding kit. Unfortunately, even though the bits come in a plastic case, the driver comes as a separate item that doesn't have a case.

Knowing how disorganized I am, I decided to whip up a quick openscad model that I can use to store the driver and the bits together.

This is a work in progress still, I have yet to actually print it myself, so beware -- this part will have further iterations.

This is a replica Roman-style wax tablet. Would have been originally made of wood, sometimes with inner leaves as well. Print the Tablet itself twice and then they can be bound together (they are not printed together - I found this more useful), and then the stylus printed separately. Usable as a fun pocket tablet, or a cool thing for history buffs to have!

(Be aware it is quite small: each tablet is slightly bigger than a playing card)

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Yes

No

Notes:

I like rafts for a cleaner surface at the end; they are optional.
Everything else was printed standard.

If so desired:

Gesso & paint with acrylic to make it look like wood (or just print with brown), bind together with twine or leather, fill in with wax (I use beeswax), and then practice your latin! (or not)

comments.text: So, you said this was small. But could I upscale it to be about the size of my hand? Also, what type of wax did you use? I want to make this for my latin class, and if I am feeling fancy I'm going to make it with woodfill lol.

comments.text: Sure! It's probably roughly the size of an adult palm now. The only concern I would have would be curling up on the sides, depending on how you print it. I just used basic beeswax ordered off amazon, relatively inexpensive, then melted it and poured it in. Good luck!

title: MK8 Bowden extruder with pivot and quick release idler

description.text:
Hi everyone I finally added a pivot to the extruder to better align it with the filament. Before the extruder was at a fixed angle placing stress on the filament, making a squeaky sound (which can be fixed by drilling the bottom hole) and in some cases of very brittle PLA even breaking the filament. Now the extruder mounts using an M4 screw to the support on the bracing M10 rod. For those who don't want to disassemble the bracing M10 rod supporting the printer (myself included) I added a simple adapter to connect to the old mounting method. (Later I realized you could probably drill out one of the old supports to 4mm but whatever.)

I also added a little tab at the top of the idler and adjacent to the fitting to allow a quick release of the filament by pinching it. As of now the one I printed was colorfabb nGen which is much softer than PLA and flexes a bit more. That along with a very strong spring make the top pinching method not work for me but it should work in PLA, let me know in the comments, eIther way it doesn't hurt.

The extruder should be printed with support touching the build plate just to hold the new little tab.

You can find the PC4-01 fitting here
http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2050601.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.A0.H0.XPC4-01.TRS5&_nkw=PC4-01&_sacat=0
About $5 shipped from the US or
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-Printer-Pneumatic-Connectors-PC4-01-1-75mm-PTFE-Tube-quick-coupler-j-head-Fittings-Reprap/32361630920.html
$0.50 from china
http://www.aliexpress.com/
Product ID: 32361630920

I ordered it on Aug 05 2016
it arrived in LA today Aug. 18 2016 so not too bad.

My son recently started occupational therapy. One of the exercises he works on focuses on answering 'yes' and 'no' questions. The therapist will ask a question, and then answer out loud while holding up the corresponding yes/no card. We didn't have any of these to use for practice at home, so I modeled up a few simple tiles.

Where we go, the 'yes' card is a yellow happy face, and the 'no' card is a red X. I have included several different options to choose from:

-- Yes Card --
Smiley Face
Sunshine Smiley Face
Check Mark
Thumbs Up

-- No Card --
Large X
Strike through Circle
Thumbs Down

A big thanks to Loubie for her great happy face designs. My son responds very well to them. I can hold out the sun card and he will shout 'YES!' with a great big smile. :)

title: Steampunk Weapons: Double Musket (28mm Scale gun)

description.text:
Steampunk Weapons: Double Musket (28mm Scale gun)
Part of my Steampunk / western collection.

This gun was inspired by the Double Hackbutt from Pathfinder and the Master Engineer of Warhammer Fantasy.

It also features more "organic" forms than my other design, trying to emulate an actual gun stock, but it's hard when working with corners and hard edges.

there's 6 parts in the files, 2 of them are meant for a normal Hackbutt with Scope. The second two can be used as either a double barrel Musket, og a double Barrel shotgun (you could cut off some of the barrel). Lastly I included the scope as a standalone, for those who might want it.

No details on this gun is less than 1mm, but you still need to print it in 100 microns or 50, to obtain many of the details.

The length of the main gun is 45mm, while the width is only 5mm.
Height W. Scope is 11.25mm
Height W.o. Scope is 8mm.

Protip: Each of the barrels are 2mm in diameter: Use a 1mm drill to emulate actual barrels after printing.

author: WRRL

title: Infant Hercules, by Julien Dillens (archival quality)

description.text:
Inspired by Cosmo Wenman, who recently wrote the following on Medium:

"It’s an inversion of the goal of creating access to a physical space. It’s taking a collection and projecting it outward so that people outside the museum can access the designs directly, wherever they happen to be.

What I’m advocating is not anticipating particular installations, particular uses, or particular audiences. It’s dumping the data online so that the users outside the museum can use it in ways that we could never anticipate or plan for."

This is a work of mysterious origin. Here is a transcript of what the seller told me--it's my favorite story of how an object like this ends up on eBay: "I found this statue about 35/40 years ago in a house that I was emptying for renovation/restoration. I kept this statue for myself, it was all this time a decorative piece on a chest in my house. And now, because none of my children are interested in it, I decided to sell it."

All I know is that the artist is the sculptor Julien Dillens [1849-1904]. There does not appear to be any record of this work, so I can only guess that the subject is an infant Hercules. Possibly he made it for his own amusement, as it is thoroughly strange and completely unlike the works he made for public monuments!

Creator: Julien Dillens [1849-1904]
Date: 1880s
Dimensions: 18 x 5 x 5 inches
Material: Terra cotta
Weight: ~7 lbs
Date Acquired: 2014-03-25
From Where?: Lommel, Limburg (Belgium)

A very special thanks to Sean O'Reilly and 3D Printsmith LLC for making this all possible. He used a calibrated structured light scanner and mapped numerous close-up shots to a macro view of the statuette.

Thank you all for downloading! I hope you enjoy it and look at it closely, it really rewards you with a wealth of detail the more you study it!

Stephen Chow
chowcollection.culturalspot.org

Direct link to the original entry here.

P.S. Let me know if you print this! I'd love to see the results. My e-mail is: [email protected]

The diameter of the Spool Axis fits in every spool I have seen, so it probably will fit in yours. It has a diameter of 25mm.

Printing suggestions:

  • For ABS: enough = 20% suggested = 50%

I hope you enjoy this!

title: Upgrade for Cowtech 3D Scanner: Laser Holders and Rotative Plate

description.text:
If any suggestions, feel free to write. By the way, this 99$ scanner ended up to cost an additional 30$ + 38$ for shipping and broker/tx fees, just saying.

Upgrade 1:
New rotative bearing holder plate with direct drive to increase the angular position accuracy. Simply install the bearing in the new part and press fit the center hole in the motor shaft. There is a flat side in the plastic part center hole to match the motor shaft flat side... So align it. Tested and much, much better. No sensible transmission anymore.

Upgrade 2:
New laser holder to increase the angular adjustement. The original one is limited in displacement and causing issues to center the laser line on the rotative plate center. (probably caused by too short acrylic arms in the kit.) Reuse directly the CTScanner-_Laser_Core_1 to fit in this new part. Holes for screws are present, but everything fit nicely together and I didn't use any.

Upgrade 3: To come soon... 3D Scanner top part to give a more finish product look.

comments.text: The rotative plate comes out 1% smaller than needed (the screw holes don't match the laser-cut plate provided in the scanner kit), so be sure to increase your printout scale in Cura (etc.) to 101% before printing.

description.text:
STEAMCraft Your Classroom is a project for students to design their classroom or create a 3D model of their classroom.

Students practice mathemetics while gathering all the data necessary and converting all the data to the appropriate scale to build the classroom in Minecraft and then 3D print it.

The design of the inside of the classroom as well as the modeling of a real classroom are added onto the complete design of the entire school campus. See STEAMCraft Your School for the campus building construction (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1725352).

While printing, keep in mind that some objects in classrooms such as whiteboards may be hanging in the air thus they may need to be glued on after printing if the walls are not printed along with the classroom.

(Note) The sample classroom furniture should actually be separated and laid flat for a cleaner print without supports. The sample is just upright because it was directly taken from Minecraft to MCEdit to PrintCraft and straight to MakerBot Desktop. Before that last step, depending on the specifics of your classroom furniture design, you would want to go into 3D modeling and separate the fixtures to position them flat against the ground with the least amount of support required.)

Create a 3D printed model of your classroom leveraging mathematics!

Overview & Background

By completing this project, educators will receive many ideas from students on different ways to redesign their classroom. Educators will also have a 3D model of their classroom to showcase at open house.

Objectives

Students will learn to practice mathematics hands-on using tape measure, rulers, string and other objects to measure the lengths of objects in their classroom. Students will need to practice addition and multiplication in order to calculate the lengths and proper scale at which to build their classroom in Minecraft.

Audiences

Depending on abilities, students in K-12 could all do this project however, the mathematics practice is appropriate for Grades K-2.

Subjects

STEAMCraft Your Classroom is an exercise in mathematics.

Skills Learned (Standards)

Know number names and the count sequence.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.A.1
Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.A.2
Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence (instead of having to begin at 1).
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.A.3
Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Count to tell the number of objects.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.B.4
Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.B.4.A
When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one and only one object.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.B.4.B
Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.B.4.C
Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.CC.B.5
Count to answer "how many?" questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1-20, count out that many objects.

Describe and compare measurable attributes.

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.MD.A.1
Describe measurable attributes of objects, such as length or weight. Describe several measurable attributes of a single object.

Classify objects and count the number of objects in each category.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.MD.B.3
Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.1

Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.G.B.4
Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/"corners") and other attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.K.G.B.5
Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components (e.g., sticks and clay balls) and drawing shapes.

Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.OA.A.1
Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.1
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.OA.A.2
Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

Add and subtract within 20.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.OA.C.5
Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.OA.C.6
Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 - 4 = 13 - 3 - 1 = 10 - 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 - 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).

Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.MD.A.1
Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.MD.A.2
Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps. Limit to contexts where the object being measured is spanned by a whole number of length units with no gaps or overlaps.

Reason with shapes and their attributes.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.G.A.1
Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.1.G.A.2
Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape.1

Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.OA.A.1
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.1
Add and subtract within 20.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.OA.B.2
Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies.2 By end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.
Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.OA.C.3
Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.OA.C.4
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.A.1
Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.A.2
Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.A.3
Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.A.4
Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.
Relate addition and subtraction to length.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.B.5
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.MD.B.6
Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, ..., and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.

Reason with shapes and their attributes.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.G.A.1
Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces.1 Identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and cubes.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.2.G.A.2
Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.

Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.5
Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.5.A
A square with side length 1 unit, called "a unit square," is said to have "one square unit" of area, and can be used to measure area.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.5.B
A plane figure which can be covered without gaps or overlaps by n unit squares is said to have an area of n square units.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.6
Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.7
Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.7.A
Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.7.B
Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.7.C
Use tiling to show in a concrete case that the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths a and b + c is the sum of a × b and a × c. Use area models to represent the distributive property in mathematical reasoning.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.C.7.D
Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.3.MD.D.8
Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.

Lesson/Activity

Duration:
Educators can create two different projects using this. One is to design an ideal classroom and the other is to model the current classroom. Then the duration of the lesson can be expanded or contracted depending on what level of detail to which educators wish to map out the classroom.

Preparation:
The preparation is the most important part to customize depending on what level of mathematics you wish to have your students practice. If measuring furniture in a Kindergarten classroom, the use of yardsticks measuring in units of "feet" would be easier. In 2nd and 3rd Grade, educators may wish to use metric units or inches. Depending on the level of math addition and multiplication/division desired, the appropriate tools must be given.

Once students have measured all the furniture in the classroom to be modeled, a conversion must be made to determine the proper scale in Minecraft. This scale should be chosen depending on what mathematics exercise the students are learning. For Kindergarten and Grade 1, simply creating a 1 foot to 1 cubic length ratio is the easiest. For Grades 2-12, educators can challenge the students to create a 2:1 scale or 3:1 scale.

To more accurately create a Minecraft model that uses the in-game items such as doors, the standard is 1 cubic length = 1 meter.

Once the Minecraft model is completed, students or educators use MCEdit to select the chunks of the classroom and export that to a schematics file.

The schematics file is then uploaded to PrintCraft to create a .stl file.

The .stl is then opened in MakerBot Desktop sofware to print.

References

STEAMCraft Your School:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1725352

Minecraft:
https://minecraft.net/

MCEdit:
http://www.mcedit.net/

PrintCraft:
http://www.printcraft.org/

Rubrics & Assessment

At the end students will have a great model to show off at open house.

If they designed a totally new idea for the classroom and everyone likes it, then it is time to REMAKE THE ROOM!

description.text: I designed this spool holder after looking around and trying a bunch of them and never getting exactly what I wanted. This is a truly universal spool holder, It will hold spool with a 30mm hole in the spool all the way up to 80mm. I kept the holder short to help with print time. Another thing I never liked about the spool holders I was finding is that they all only used one bearing in each cone and they never spin very well, each one of the cones in my design use two 608zz bearings and the spool can spin like its sitting on butter. It works very well!

Put one 608zz bearing in each side of each cone so that the bearings are flush with the edge. So you will use a total of 4 bearings.

Remixed from jedimasta's Dragonborn fighter. I had difficulty printing the original because of how thin the sword was - so I used Blender to remove the original curved sword and replace it with a couple other options.

Both are generated with OSCADSharp/OpenSCAD. One manually and one from a simplified image of a greatsword.

comments.text: Sure - no criticism intended!  Thanks for making the original :)
comments.author: jedimasta

description.text: The famous Running Man from the Mattel Intellivision.

Just thought I'd upload the OpenSCAD sword that I made for the alternate swords on my Dragonborn D&D character variants.

(Which can be found here)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1726928

Feel free to use this sword for your own figurines!

I liked WillPio's medieval mace http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1571743. He used a table leg for the handle, but I didn't have one handy so I made a simple printable handle in 2 parts. I also added the spike to the head of the mace, it can easily be printed as one piece.

comments.text: Nice work. I like the update to the tip also.

description.text: F-14D Super Tomcat ready to print.

comments.text: Very hard? Ok, this file is a low-res STL but I can imagine the original with all the cockpit detail and the U/C !!! You really have something there! What was the original model done in?
comments.author: mmorao

comments.text: And I would like to clarify what do you mean by 'U/C'?
comments.author: mmorao

comments.text: The original model was created from scratch in Sketchup. All the work includes the research and implementing them into SketchUp. Do you have any recommendations on what software I should use?
comments.author: mmorao

comments.text: U/C goes for undercarriage :) I did start with Sketchup but I began to find it lacking. It does a lot, especially when you start loading it with the constellation of plug-ins available, but still the way it manages (or doesn't) small geometries and how it creates unintended interactions between elements that pass close by each other made me wish to throw it away as far from me as I could. But in any case doing a model like this F-14 in SK is an achievement by itself, and that is speaking a lot re your abilities.
comments.author: 3DimensionPrinter

comments.text: Thank you very much for your reply! Yes, I am currently in High School (Or as I have been taught, "College" in America, me living in Australia). I already own Autodesk AutoCAD but I never really got into using it. Do you recommend me to get into it? I also tried Blender, but it was too confusing. (I was a lot younger then, though)
comments.author: mmorao

comments.text: CV is Curriculum Vitae, aka your résumé :-)  Blender can be quite daunting for those who face the beast for the first time, but I've seen amazing work done in it by real masters.so somehow it works. However with my work pressures I doubt I could afford the time for long periods to dive in training in what is not really an engineering tool as I require.
comments.author: 3DimensionPrinter

comments.text: Thank you! I absolutely hate pirating and I strongly am against it.

comments.text: A fine Thing, here!  A few questions:  1.  Is this cat a professional model?  2.  Assuming the answer is "yes," what agency did you use?  3.  Does the agency sell cats who have been trained to tolerate all sorts of humiliating treatment by humans? 4.  Were artificial fasteners used (e.g., super glue, duct tape, staples, etc.) to affix the hat to the cat's head?
comments.author: Loftonharris

comments.text: All excellent questions. 1. This is a complicated answer. Schmissile was a professional model, he went into seclusion and called himself Schmissile Twolander for awhile. 2. He was provided to us by a lovely agency named Mugatu's Glamor Kitties LLC. 3. Is there any other type of cat model? 4. After several iterations including hot glue, rivets, and left over binder clips for fastening the glass to the heat bed, I settled on these elastic hair band straps from Target.

author: Jipsy

title: Wide mouth mason jar strainer/shaker with lid

description.text:
My first (sad) attempt at something really useful. I REALLY hope others more knowledgeable than I will take this idea and run with it. I'd be the first in line to print out their version!

I've recently gotten into making homemade everything-I-can-think-of, like laundry detergent (simple) and carpet powder (also very simple). What I really wanted was a convenient way to store and use the carpet powder. AlexEnglish's Canning Jar Strainer Lid caught my eye, but it didn't have a cover. So, after several back and forths using Autodesk's 123D Design, this is my take on adding a hinge and cover to it.

I printed this out using PLA. Hence the reinforcement clip and very thick lid. I just used CA glue to attach the reinforcement clip to the lid.
It might require some mild filing, depending on your printer's capabilities. Mine is calibrated fairly well, but the hinge was a bit tight. Working it back and forth for a while loosened it up, on mine. Again, I'm hoping someone more knowledgeable will improve on this idea.

i3 clone

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Resolution:

100 microns

20%. Your decision.

A robust handle for sabre saw blades.
Comes with a "storage hole" for an hex key.

Notice that all those machine sabre saw blades have a reversed toothing.
They will cut while you pull the blade out, in contrast to an ordinary hand saw which will cut while pushing the blade in...

I recommend printing this upright, as prepared in the STL files and an appropriate amount of infill ;-) BOM:
  • 2 x M8 nut
  • 1 x M5 nut
  • 1 x magnet, (5x5x5)mm
  • 3 x M3 nut
  • 3 x M3 x 20 screw (Allan, cylinder head)
  • A drop of glue to fix the magnet.
  • 2mm hex key
    • Compatible with sabre saw blades from:
  • AEG (Atlas Copco)
  • Black & Decker
  • Bosch
  • DeWalt
  • Flex
  • Hitachi
  • Lenox
  • Makita

This is designed for an iPhone 6 using 123D design. The design took me roughly one hour to print with 30% density and 0.2mm layer height which used up around 4.5 metres of ABS plastic. I use this on my desk when I am on my computer so I am able to easily read notifications without picking up my device.

Suggestions:

  • Coat plastic in epoxy glue for a shiny look and extra strength, make sure to let it dry or your phone may stick to the stand
  • Use raft to prevent plastic bending when being printed
  • Use glue when assembling the rods
  • Use acetone on the rods to remove thin layers of plastic if it doesn't fit in the holes

title: Prusa Mount for Makerbot mk7 Extruder

description.text: I am working on a direct drive extruder using MakerGear components. The aluminum block that mounts the hot end to the extruder has a mounting footprint compatible with the Makerbot mk7 (and mk8) extruders. This mounting plate will mount both types of extruder to a Prusa X-Carriage. There are many reasons you probably shouldn't use this part not the least of which is that I have never tried it with a Makerbot hot end and it may very well mash the hot end right into your X carriage. And since you don't have my experimental MG hot end mount you are out of luck for now! Here's a video of it in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xyMfSAiMk0I Update: I had to make another one out of 1/8" Aluminum plate because the wooden version let the heat travel too far up the barrel. It extruded fine as long as you kept going but if you stopped for a while it would get very sticky.

Laser cut from 3mm plywood (or probably better if you truly plan to use a Makerbot extruder, from 1/16" stainless steel).
Installation is a bit tricky:  First mount the aluminum block to the adapter by sliding it in through the slot and twisting it into place.  Then drop screws through the mounting holes and secure on the X carriage.  Bolt the heatsink/fan combination to the front of the block and the motor to the back (this will cover one or both of the mounting screws).

print_settings.Notes:: I used custom supports using Simplify3D to provide supports in the open windows of the body, and also under the top cover.

description.text:
My new Amazon Echo is a bit lacking in "curb appeal", so I decided to make a house for her to more represent my personality. Echo fits nicely inside, but all of her Microphones, Speaker Holes, Function Buttons, and Top Lights are fully visible and functional.

Update: For those who are using printers capable of printing taller items, I have added the 1 piece base file. I am not able to print this, so the file has not been tested, though I am confident the file is sound.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm/layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used custom supports using Simplify3D to provide supports in the open windows of the body, and also under the top cover.

Due to the size limits of my printer, I was forced to break this into 3 parts. Simply take the base and upper pieces and put them together. For those with larger build areas, there is no reason to print the split base files separately. You would just need to print the tall base file and the top. If you are using the split base version,be sure to align the door faces so your Tardis looks correct. Pull the power cord up through the base and plug into your Echo. Then, while sliding the Echo into the tower, slowly pull the slack back out of the unit on the cord. When you place the unit it, be sure it is turned in such a way to allow access to both function buttons when the top is placed on.
This was designed using TinkerCad online.

title: Tentacle chess pawn (model the other pieces yourself!)

description.text: This is a chess pawn for an underwater themed chess set. I thought it would be funny to have 8 tentacles as the pawns. The other pieces are yet to be modeled and should, in my opinion be a conch shell as tower, a seahorse as knight, a lobster as bishop, the tail of a whale as queen and an oyster with a pear as king.I WOULD LIKE YOU ALL TO HELP MODEL THESE, if you like the idea! Pleas join! Pick one and start modeling!

I made this in maya by using the soft modification tool on a cone shape and then putting adjusted torus shapes on it. It was printed with a layer height of 0.2 in about 50 minutes for a 6,8 mm high model. I modeled it so it can be printed without support.
It was inspired by this: http://www.behance.net/gallery/Bishop/3012527
If you'd prefer to turn it in to a fridge magnet or a usb or something, thats fine, show me what you've made!

title: Bosch Refridgerator temperature control cover (Bosch koolkast, refrigerator)

description.text:
Our refridgerator works just fine (i.e. it gets on with keeping stuff cool) but for one irritating feature: When you place items on the top shelf it's possible to accidentally adjust the temperature. This results in things near the back of the refridgerator being frozen.

This 3D printed piece of plastic solves the problem by blocking the temperature control. It requires nothing to keep it in place - it's a good fit on top of the control. Probably works on a range of Bosch refridgerators. Ours is the model KIR1832/01.

title: Blanco Fracture Zone, Eastern Pacific
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Two models of the Blanco Fracture Zone, located in the eastern Pacific off the coast of Oregon, USA: 1:2,000,000 and 1:5,000,000.  Both  models print with a size of 150mm.  
Both models have a vertical exaggeration of 5X.

These bathymetry models were created using data obtained from the NOAA National Geophysical Data Center (http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/bathymetry/). The tools required were MapWindowGIS (www.mapwindow.org) and Sketchup (sketchup.com) with the "Heightmap to Mesh" plugin. Cleanup was done with Netfabb and Meshlab (www.netfabb.com, meshlab.sourceforge.net, respectively). See the link below for how these and other bathymetry and elevation models are being used in an educational setting. https://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2013AM/webprogram/Paper232739.htmll

Update 5 Nov 2013:  We have added several files under the "Thing Files" tab that includes our inspiration of Universal Design for geoscience education (reported as a poster at a recent Geological Society of America meeting), map scales conversion to use conventional scales often taught in introductory-level college geology courses, an .mp4 video walking through the workflow and freeware used...including the real data (x-y-z coordinates) sources, transcript of the video for better accessibility, and other education-related resource about why we "do" this.

title: Connector Pieces for Halo 4 Helmet Size A (no magnets/tension pins required)

description.text: Given my impatient personality, I didn't want to wait for magnets and tension pins to arrive in the mail to put together this AWESOME Halo 4 Helmet made by big_red_frog. I also don't like the messiness of gluing. So, I created these connector pieces you can print out instead. Each one takes 3-5 minutes to print. I tried printing 20 at a time, but due to minor imperfections when printing multiple small pieces on one build plate, the cylinders won't be strong unless you print one at a time. So, I recommend you don't print multiple pieces at once. Instead, print one piece at a time. This requires that you sit right next to your printer and repeatedly press "print" every 3 minutes, so pick your favorite TV show and get crackin'! I printed using Makerware's Standard resolution settings. Original Halo Helmet can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158120

Hi Runningfox, the helmet is a fixed size. So these connectors are designed to fit into the helmet.
The original creator created multiple helmet sizes, however. For example, here is a child size: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:181491http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
As long as the holes to fit in the visor are the same in the Child version as the Adult version, these connectors will work just fine.
You can then put foam pads/a cloth/towel/sponges inside the helmet so that it fits around you or your kid's head nicely.

comments.author: DFD007

title: Key style filament guides for the Geeetech Acrylic Prusa i3

description.text:
The edges of the display board of the Geetech acrylic Prusa i3 are rather sharp and filament fed from behind the printer tends to rub against them or even get pulled in the corner the display board and the main upper bridge forms.

So I designed a few things that are supposed to make the filament run over that edge more smoothly.

The first variant is closed, so you need to slice it open or ensure to have the filament run through it when loading.
The second (Key2) is sliced in half on the clip-on side to allow for inserting the filament.
The third (Key4) has on opening hook mechanism at the front. Best for me so far.

author: cpstockstill

description.text:
Rather than using cone filters and other comparable intakes, I have began prototyping this velocity stack. There is said to be advantages in the way the air is introduced into the carburetor via velocity stacks. The idea is that the air is allowed to gradually curve and flow into the carb. With other methods, the air abruptly gets sucked into the intake with added turbulence. This turbulence can cause your fuel and air mixture to be inconsistent.  
This is designed around a 54mm intake port for a Honda CB750.
Print with .2mm or better layer height. I used .1mm. 10-15% infill. Print with opening or flare facing down.

comments.text: Nice work,
comments.author: fpinczuk

comments.text: Nice. I'm currently working on a similar project for my CB750. Although, I'm designing the model as a mold (oversized a few mil) so that i can wrap the internal surface with carbon fiber and vacuum infuse it.
comments.author: MakerRuss

comments.text: I am also interested to know if this worked out. I recently purchased an old yamaha triple, and put some triumph carbs on it. They have oval intake ports, so they are a little unusual. I am wondering if I could just print up some velocity stacks.
comments.author: CafeRocker

comments.text: Nice!
comments.author: bram2202

comments.text: Any issues with heat?
comments.author: DanMoto

comments.text: you should make some with screens in them so you don't have to worry about debris in the carbs
comments.author: jpetersen

comments.text: i found somewhere online little "booties" specifically made for V stacks but i'm sure you could make your own.
comments.author: jpetersen

comments.text: That's a good idea. I had planned on buying some thin screen material, but that could work. Although, it would become a bit tougher print with the overhang and or support material. Good thinking nonetheless.
